qas.question: What did the Magna Charta Universitatum say students were allowed?
What marked the 430th anniversary of Bologna's foundation?

context: An important idea in the definition of a university is the notion of <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>academic freedom<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. The first documentary evidence of this comes from early in the life of the first university. <b7_0>The <a1_0><b10_0>University of Bologna<b10_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/> adopted an academic charter, <a2_0><b6_0>the <b11_0>Constitutio Habita<b11_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>, in 1158 or 1155, which guaranteed the right of a traveling scholar to <a3_0><b8_0><b12_0>unhindered passage<b8_0/> in the interests of education<b12_0/><a3_0/>. Today this is claimed as the origin of "academic freedom". This is now widely recognised internationally - on <a4_0>18 September 1988<a4_0/>, 430 university rectors signed the <b13_0>Magna Charta Universitatum<b13_0/>, marking the 900th anniversary of Bologna's foundation. The number of universities signing the Magna Charta Universitatum continues to grow, drawing from all parts of the world.
